title: Ritual Cache

thumbnail.alt_text: Carved ceremonial objects colored with orange and blue of a man, woman, snake, curved sticks, and cougar.

artist_display:
Salado branch of the Mogollon
New Mexico, United States
description: Discovered wrapped and hidden in a remote, dry cave, this cache of ritual figures comes from the Salado culture, which flourished in the mountains of southwestern New Mexico and southeastern Arizona between the fourteenth and fifteenth centuries. Brilliantly colored and adorned with flicker feathers and dyed cotton string, these effigies once formed an altar as agents for communion with the life-giving spirits of the earth and sky. The large male figure, with his feather necklace and bold black-and-turquoise zigzag pattern, features sky symbolism. The smaller, female figure is a more self-contained form, probably corresponding to the earth. Her ocher color likely refers to maize and pollen, symbols of sustenance and fertility. The accompanying figures are a mountain lion (the chief predator in the region) and two serpents (carved from cottonwood roots), representing agents of communication with the earth and the seasonal cycle of fertility. Curved wooden throwing sticks for rabbit hunting complete the ensemble. Testimony to the antiquity and endurance of the worship of earth and sky and to the spiritual bonds between people and animals, these objects bear close resemblance to ritual figures and implements still used today among the diverse Pueblo peoples.
dimensions: Male figure: H.: 64 cm (25 1/4 in.); Female figure: H.: 36 cm (14 3/16 in.)
medium_display: Wood, stone, plant fibers, cotton, feathers, hide, and pigment
publication_history: Henry Jerome Walt, "An Effigy Cache from the Cliff Valley, New Mexico" (unpublished MA Thesis, University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, 1978). Alan G. Artner, "Art Institute Acquires Rare Sacred Altar of Mimbres," Chicago Tribune, Tempo section, June 19, 1979 (ill.). Charles Leroux and Marianne Taylor, "Relics' Popularity Endangers their Historical Value," Chicago Tribune, Tempo section, June, 19, 1979 (ill.). Evan Maurer, "A Mimbres Altar Group," Bulletin of the Art Institute of Chicago 73, 4 (July-August 1979): 2–6 (ill.). Rodger Friedman, "Museum Purchase of Artifacts Poses Questions for the Future," The New Mexico Independent 84, 5 (1979): 6-7 (ill.). College Art Association, “Acquisitions,” Art Journal 39, 1 (Fall 1979): 62. Art Institute of Chicago, Junior Museum Family Programs [leaflet] (Chicago: Art Institute of Chicago, 1985). Gene Stuart, America's Ancient Cities (Washington, DC: National Geographic Society, 1988), 88 (ill.). United States Postage Stamp (United States Post Office, 1989) (male figure, ill.). Louis Argend-Farlow, Art and Ethnography: Interpreting the Iconography of a Prehistoric Puebloan Altar Group (unpublished Master’s Thesis, University of Texas at Austin, Dec. 1989). Richard F. Townsend, ed., The Ancient Americas: Art from Sacred Landscapes, exh. cat. (Chicago: Art Institute of Chicago/Prestel Verlag, 1992), cover, 87, 378 (ill.). Neil Harris, Chicago’s Dream, a World’s Treasure: The Art Institute of Chicago, 1893–1993, exh. cat., Teri J. Edelstein, ed. (Chicago: Art Institute of Chicago, 1993), 59, pl. 34 (ill). David Penney and George Longfish, Native American Art (New York: Universe and Hugh Lauter Levin Assoc., 1994), 135 (ill.). James N. Wood, ed., Treasures from The Art Institute of Chicago (Chicago: Art Institute of Chicago, 2000), 33 (ill.). Art Institute of Chicago, The Art Institute of Chicago: The Essential Guide, revised ed. (Chicago: Art Institute of Chicago, 2003), 17 (ill.). Richard F. Townsend, ed., Casas Grandes and the Ceramic Art of the Ancient Southwest, exh. cat. (Chicago: Art Institute of Chicago/Yale University Press, 2006), 187, plate 126 (ill.). Art Institute of Chicago, Pocket Guide (Chicago: Art Institute of Chicago, 2009), 4 (male figure, ill.). Art Institute of Chicago, The Art Institute of Chicago: The Essential Guide, revised edition (Chicago: Art Institute of Chicago, 2009), 21 (ill.). Richard F. Townsend and Kathleen Bickford Berzock, “The Art Institute of Chicago New Galleries,” in Tribal Arts XVI-1/62 (Winter 2011): 63, fig. 10 (ill.). Katherine Dungan, “Faces of Salado?” Archaeology Southwest, Preservation Archaeology Blog, https://www.archaeologysouthwest.org/2013/10/30/faces-of-salado/ Richard Townsend with Elizabeth Pope, Indian Art of the Americas at the Art Institute of Chicago (Chicago: Art Institute of Chicago and Yale University Press, 2016), 59, cat. 25 (ill.).
exhibition_history: Art Institute of Chicago, The Ancient Americas: Art from Sacred Landscapes, Oct. 10, 1992–Jan. 3, 1993, cat. 150; Houston, Museum of Fine Arts, Feb. 4–Apr. 18, 1993; Los Angeles County Museum of Art, June 6–Aug. 15, 1993. Art Institute of Chicago, Chicago’s Dream, A World’s Treasure: The Art Institute, 1893–1993, Nov. 1, 1993–Jan. 9. 1994, cat. Art Institute of Chicago, Casas Grandes and the Ceramic Art of the Ancient Southwest, Apr. 22–Aug. 13, 2006, cat. plate 126.
provenance_text: Unnamed collector, New Mexico, about 1972 [reportedly found in Cliff Valley, NM, according to statement in curatorial object file, Arts of the Americas; on loan to Maxwell Museum of Anthropology, Albuquerque, NM, for scientific analysis, see Walt, May 1978]; sold to private collection, Mesa, AZ, July 25, 1978 [notarized Bill of Sale in curatorial object file, Arts of the Americas]; sold partial interest to Jonathan Holstein, New York, and Philip Holstein, Jr., Aspen, CO, Aug. 18, 1978 [copy of Bill of Sale in curatorial object file, Arts of the Americas]; sold to the Art Institute of Chicago, 1979.
